castAddBody.text: Apple recently blocked release of our mobile wallet app that displays NFT of users as well as shows QR codes for IRL ownership verification. Not sure if it is a recent change to their rule but I think it affects other apps that interact with NFT too. Let me share our experience.

We submitted the app two weeks ago, after the news that says Apple allowing NFT sales in apps but requiring IAP for the sales. Our app is a typical wallet app which have nothing to do with NFT sales so we didn‚Äôt think the updated guidelines would affect us.

Shortly after submission, we were asked some questions about NFT. Because our app provides only features are are common to crypto wallet and it has nothing about sales, we thought it was just a routine. https://i.imgur.com/7gh5QvN.jpg

We replied and then the app was quickly rejected. We thought it was just one of the reviewers who applied the rule too strict. So we remove some features that might have triggered the rejection such as link to OpenSea and built-in web3 browser.

After many back and forth, we got this rejection that is alarming. Basically, it says clearly that just by viewing a user‚Äôs NFTs would require IAP, even if we don‚Äôt sell any of them. https://i.imgur.com/jDoVrFp.jpg

Thanks for sharing. Apple rejected our app with issues different than those in the article. They rejected because our app allow users to view their NFT as they said clearly. I really hope it is just an human error of Apple side (so we appealed) rather than a explicit rule change
We hope it is just some reviewers being too zealous rather than a rule change coming from Apple. How is your experience with submitting apps with NFT function recently?

Thinking to trying to start a weekend project on top of Farcaster (perhaps Twitter Spaces for Farcaster). What is the current best way to allow users to login their Farcaster identity on browser? Also, any API documentation?
I would say it is the tiny group of like-minded people and at the same time have diversity. Feel like BBS in early Internet. But the challenge is whether this vibe could be kept when more users come.

We all know that tweets are the worst possible format for nuanced discussions. However, people still like to debate a lot on Twitter because it is where the audiences are. What design and functions do you want to make discourses in social network more constructive?
Thanks. But for some reasons I couldn‚Äôt have it working https://i.imgur.com/00TGobd.jpg

Totally agree Twitter is optimizing for anger (and attention). But I also have to admit that it is engaging. When people build DSN today, they often model after Twitter (like Farcaster). I just wonder what change can we make to improve the discourses while keeping the fun.
I think expressing one‚Äôs own opinion should be encouraged isn‚Äôt it? It is the way of expressing become problematic sometimes.

tbh I think most cases SBT can be substituted with just signed messages or more formally with Verifiable Credentials. You can have on chain code verify signature/VC easily. On the other hand, verifying SBT offline is much more difficult. Also, SBT has worse privacy

PayPal told #HongKong pro-democracy political party League of Social Democrats that they terminated their account due to ‚Äúexcessive risks,‚Äù cutting off large sum of donations to LSD. Who said crypto has no use in payment must be thankful they live in a functioning democracy.
The idea is great but I am it will is not going to passApple‚Äôs App Store Review. They have a guideline that specifically ban in-app App Store.
Have you checked out delegate.cash? https://0xfoobar.substack.com/p/delegatecash

I do think the Circles concept in Google+ is quite interesting. Basically, organizing the feed by clans. The problem was that it was too much work to maintain the circles. Wouldn‚Äôt it be interesting if the circles were managed automatically by algorithm?
Staying in Taiwan üáπüáº for about a month. Any interesting people there?
Why doesn‚Äôt users in web3 being called users? Even they use wallets it is still the users who create the content. We don‚Äôt call web2 ‚Äúbrowser generated content‚Äù.

My issue is that it badly capture benefits of web3 to people. Wallet is a pseudonym of the person who control the private key. Pseudonymous isn‚Äôt new, and Twitter handle can be said a pseudonym too. Confusing and cringing marketing slangs in crypto is already too many.

gm

I know the crypto community isn‚Äôt keen on lawmaking, but imo legislation and antitrust lawsuits are the biggest weapon to force Apple to open up the App Store. WPA can‚Äôt compete with native apps in near terms because it is not in Apple and Google‚Äôs interest.

What you think the biggest design issues are in Twitter besides it is centralized? What is your approach to fix them? (I am all for decentralization, but I am also interested in designing better social networks)

Edited an earlier blog post. Although the topic is about Web5, it is more a discussion on non-technical challenges of designing a decentralized systems today. https://medium.com/on-top-of-ruins/my-thoughts-on-web5-7ef57f4f226f

I think it is not that easy. There is no reliable way for the code determine a transfer being a sale, transfer between owner‚Äôs wallet, or a loan collateral (later 2 should be free). And there are marketplaces that execute the transaction off-chain.

It is legitimate for owner to move their NFTs for security, consolidation, or whatever reason they want. It doesn‚Äôt make sense for BAYC owners to pay $2,500 when they move wallets, right? Then, how the contract prevent marketplaces pretending to be wallets moving?

Anyone here using Lens Protocol? I am doing some research for a blog post and digging into their contract activities. It appears many of the interactions are fake or low quality. I don‚Äôt have an account so I am not sure. What does an actual user journey look like there?
What‚Äôs the problem with an identify being transferable? Twitter handle and domain name are transferable too.

True if only measured in terms of effectiveness of amplifying one‚Äôs voice. But not all voices are amplified equally. In retrospect, mobs and angry voices are amplified way too effective and it is the curse of the internet.
Conceptually there are quite a lot of similarities between AT and Farcaster V2. But we like running code (as in Farcaster) more than spec.

I think people will eventually ditching public sphere social network platforms‚Äîmany already did. They either go to algorithmic curated channels like TikTok, or closed-group social like Discord. In am interested in which direction Farcaster will go

Yes, of course. No doubt that Farcaster team delivered a great product, even compared with web2 social networks it is still above par.

What do you think about communities in reddits? I generally think that moderation is needed to keep the toxic stuffs out, but moderation should be done by individual communities who define their rules.
Closures as in programming? In what context?

Closure is a function that capture surrounding state state. The concept came from functional programming paradigm so it is commonly used together with higher order functions (like those functions in py‚Äôs functools) and map/filter/reduce functions. Closure can substitute functools.partial; it is just more general
You can select all in the album. But I didn‚Äôt have good experience on move a lot of photos in photo app.

My hope: open up their API like 2010‚Äôs; adopt AT proto from their own Bluesky team. There would be an interesting competition between Twitter and Farcaster. Much like the race between WWW and Gopher

AT protocol from Bluesky is pretty similar, but they didn‚Äôt launch their app yet. One thing that Farcaster did right is to launch their app first before struggling with the ideal architecture, and  has good taste in choosing the pilot users.

I think the challenges of a decentralized social network are mostly not tech. AT and Farcaster are alike in many ways. But Bluesky has an insistence on shipping a perfect protocol before shipping the app, which slow their iterations. Now Twitter is in Musk‚Äôs hand. I hope he will get some bits of AT into Twitter.

In the early days of Internet there was a phrase ‚ÄúWe reject: kings, presidents, and voting. We believe in: rough consensus and running code‚Äù. Farcaster is more akin to to this ethos by shipping a functioning and enjoyable product first then iterate the v2, v3, etc protocol. I like this.
Perhaps some crypto skeptics to balance out. I missed early internet‚Äôs flame wars.

Instead of wallet for finance, I imagine it will become a wallet for identities and people use it in both cyber and near space. But today‚Äôs computing environments are walled gardens, it will have to be built by the OS to become mainstream.

I think many get the analogy wrong. The point isn‚Äôt making the tech really easy to use. It is about opening to amateur innovation. It doesn‚Äôt have to be easy for the mass. But it has to be fun for people who are not financially motivated to play with it. Indeed I think web3 is failing by this metric.

Welcome

In my experience, either go all remote or all IRL. All remote works when majority of your team is senior and don‚Äôt need much coaching. Any kind of hybrid mode are going to kill your company quickly.

All communication tools we have today are designed for either remote (e.g. Slack) or IRL (e.g. whiteboards) environment. Hybrid will almost certainly result in part of the team being isolated from conversations. It is fatal for startups when they absolutely need to be fast and adapt to changes.

What does ‚Äúspam receives‚Äù refer to here?

Echo that tx reversal should be kept away from base layer protocol. Better wallet UX and send/accept semantic works better than reversal in mitigating mistaken sends. Escrow built-in a marketplace is better than reversal. One remaining problem is thefts and hacks. Maybe AA and smart contract wallets mitigate this.
For this issue, a protocol for on-chain signaling of rejection/return would be better than an extra accept phrase. Signaling solves unsolicited receives without adding complexity to normal txs.
Please welcome my friend  ! He is a book author, blogger, and creator of several crypto projects.

I don‚Äôt know. If I have the power  to increase life expectancy but cannot make human living in a more sustainable way with a fairer society, I would probably do nothing because it will mean more suffering.
Merkle app can possibly add WalletConnect support and eliminates step 1-2. It will be even better if Merkle supports push to approve instead of QR code. Not sure if there is anything in  road map.

The main purpose for a blockchain (as in cryptocurrency) is to form consensus on tx serialization. However, Farcaster doesn‚Äôt need this property. Eventual consistent with CRDT is sufficient and much more efficient. Engineering is about real world trade-offs, a single solution that fix everything doesn‚Äôt exist.

IMO, ability to delete isn‚Äôt a good argument. Deletion can‚Äôt be guaranteed once public since anyone on the network may keep a copy. Farcaster allows hubs to remove deleted data, but it is an optimization not a guarantee.

It is not specific to web3; it is the nature of information. Web2 giants can respect your will to delete something only because your information is inside silos controlled by these giants (also because of laws such as GDPR). When information is free, it is always harder to take back (e.g. in Usenet or the original web)
TCP/IP won the Internet protocol competition for sure. But I wouldn‚Äôt say the web as its original idea has won. Contrarily, I think the interconnected web is losing to walled-garden apps.

Ethereum ~ TCP/IP
So, to answer your original question, yes, I think a winner have to be chosen at that level for the whole thing to work. And I bet on Ethereum for this. It is the only L1 that has real technology development rn.

What do you think about Nostr, in terms of architecture/protocol design?

The sync-based architecture of Farcaster is very suited to become an interplanetary social network. Mars settlements could have Hubs to sync with Hubs in the Earth via a delay-tolerant network. Propagation time is around 20 min but it is certainly a reasonable user experience to Martians.
I think it is actually a great idea.

Due to the constant motion of planets and orbiters, communication links would be lossy and intermittent. IP/UDP would have an unacceptably low delivery rate. But there are researches on delay-tolerant networking (DTN) that tackle this. Farcaster can be an app layer on top of future interplantary internet protocol.

Why? Open source projects I know of tends to die very often, in many cases too fast

There are many architectures. Does it need causal consistent or it is good with eventual consistent? Libp2p is a good starting point for gossip and DHT. Then you may need state reconciliation to handle missed gossip messages. Commonly based on merkle tree or bloom/cuckoo filter.

Older decentralized message board projects used Kademlia (which is basically all modern DHT like libp2p and BitTorrent mainline). Lookup is too slow to be useful. And someone need to constantly refresh values in a DHT due to nodes going offline, which is a burden to users especially on mobile.

Gossip + reconciliation (some use the term ‚Äúanti-entropy‚Äù) architecture is a pragmatic choice for what Farcaster need. But there are other reconciliation algo besides MPT that worth considering, such as bloom/cuckoo filter based methods becoz they allow 1RRT  reconciliation. And then there are variants for each met
Love it

An overview on Bloom filter in set reconciliation problem: https://www.sciopen.com/article_pdf/1496650997615357954.pdf 

Also, Merkle Search Tree is another merkle tree based anti-entropy method that is worth considering https://hal.inria.fr/hal-02303490/document

In the context of state reconciliation, merkle tree is used to efficiently find differences in two peers. i.e. in O(log m) round trips. The differences can be arbitrary, not necessarily a subset of another. This method is commonly used in distributed DB like Dynamo and Cassandra.

Do you know that Internet Protocol has a revenue model too? ICANN is funded by registries, registrars, and new gTLD. And .org domain funds Internet Society, which hosts IETF, which is the standards body of all internet protocols. These orgs serves governance (ICANN) and forum (IETF) functions for the Internet.

These orgs are indeed more transparent and accountable than many dapps and DAOs (look at Uniswap). ICANN is a multistakeholder model which composed of different organizations (the Empowered Community). These orgs have power to raise agenda and vote for some Board seats. The power is legally enforceable by the bylaws.

Board is legally obligated to publish meeting minutes. Empowered Community can request Board to revisit a decision, or discuss and vote for issues in global meetings. Sure, Board and executive team do meet behind door, but major decisions and policy are obligated to be public.

Also, ICANN is one member one vote. Powerful members have the same vote as a grassroot members. On the other hand, did Uniswap Lab disclose any info when they take money from big VC? Maybe Uniswap isn‚Äôt a good example. What is the best dapp/DAO model in terms of governance?

The mathematical enforcement in DAO applies to treasury spending only. The controlling entity legally has no fiduciary duty in acting according to DAO. 

For investment syndicate DAO, like Orange DAO, this model does work very well. But tbh I can‚Äôt see any benefits of DAO in decentralized protocol governance.

A quick technical review üßµ on AT Protocol (Bluesky) and Farcaster.

Both protocols have quite similar objectives, but they have very different design.

First, identity. Both want account portability where user can migrate identity to a new service provider without existing server‚Äôs cooperation (unlike Fediverse).

Account portability is achieved by having handles that resolve into pubkeys that sign messages. Thus data can be authenticated regardless of the location.

Both have 2 identifiers: a stable identifier that is not very readable (FID in FC and DID in ATP) and a readable and changeable handle (FNAME and DNS name). 2/n

ATP embraces generic standards in their design such as DID and DNS, which is good for extensibility and interoperability. However, in current implementation, they use their own DID method called DID Placeholder (PLC) because they aren‚Äôt satisfied with existing DID methods. 3/n

PLC relies on a centralized "PLC server" to store the signed DID document (analogize to FID smart contract of FC). It is named ‚ÄúPlaceholder‚Äù because it is temporary and expected to be replaced by a decentralized alternative. 4/n

In ATP, user handles are DNS names that resolves into DIDs. Contrary to popular belief, DNS is an okay option as decentralized identities if you accept that ICANN‚Äôs multistakeholder governance model is sufficiently neutral. The problem of DNS is more about UX. 5/n

The legacy system of registry and registrar makes it hard to be fully automated (even if we ignore the fees). Thus, most users would rely on subdomain names offered by service providers (e.g. *.bsky.social) because setting up DNS is too technical. But this possibly defeats the purpose of account portability. 6/n

On the other hand, FC has a specialized identity system built with Ethereum smart contracts. FC‚Äôs approach has several advantages. Interactions with smart contracts can be fully abstracted away from users. FID is a simple number which is minimally usable on its own, contrary to the hash in PLC DID. 7/n

(cont) FNAME fee revenue can be used to fund the development of the protocol directly where DNS registration fee won‚Äôt go to ATP; and FNAME is shorter than DNS names. But FID/FNAME will need its own governance structure to make it truly decentralized. 8/n

Next, the network architecture. Both protocols want to offers some level of censorship resilience, and both assume that apps need to ingest all content in the network to provide useful functions such as content discovery (algorithms) and user search. 9/n

ATP achieves it by distinguishing between small-world and big-world. Small-world is a network that encompasses inter-personal activity, and big-world aggregates activities in the larger network. Personal Data Servers (PDS) are responsible for the small-world while apps use indexing services for the big-world. 10/n

FC Hub essentially combines small-world and big-world, with Hubs responsible for storing and disseminating every user‚Äôs data.

In FC, messages are disseminated in a gossip-based P2P protocol. ATP 2-worlds design is more hierarchical in which PDS and indexers uses a HTTP-based protocol to sync messages from a PDS. 11/

In ATP, the small-world (i.e. PDS) is user-owned and hence it offers censorship resilience similar to the web. The big-world is provided by larger service providers and it is inevitable that censorship (or moderation) happens in this layer. 12/n
However, it means that ATP users either have to run their PDS in a home server, or look for a service provider that run it for them. Either way is a friction to user adoption. 13/n

By the way, both protocols use merkle tree for synchronization. ATP uses Merkle Search Tree while FC uses Merkle Patricia Trie. But they differs in that each ATP user has a individual tree and user signs the tree‚Äôs root, while FC has a tree that represents the world‚Äôs state and user signs their own messages. 14/n

ATP makes moderation and spam filtering easier because PDS and indexers are free to ignore some users when syncing. FC makes it easier to sync the world‚Äôs state, but spams may become a problem because there is no obvious way for Hub to selectively ignore some users. 15/n

üå∂Ô∏è take: started to think AT Proto‚Äôs small-world/big-world architecture is better than Farcaster Hub in terms of simpler implementation, easier amateur operation, data permanence, and extensibility.

Hub is small world + big world in one construct. AT assumes big world run by big guys (think infura/alchemy) while small world can be kept simple. Hub have to make trade-off on message size limits and no permanent storage to reduce resource needed to run Hub.
Yes, but it is extra complexity to Hub. And the conservative message size limit and lack of data permanence is really a big limitation.

The small world network is very much like a federation network e.g. Mastodon. PDS only get followed users posts from other PDS. So, individual PDS scale linearly to number of users and followings. And the big world are run by entities who has the need to index all data, so they require more resource.

The problem of defederation in Mastodon is its convolution of technical (e.g. reliability, security) and political (i.e content policy) issues. ATP is different that PDS are relieved of content policy. Since user and data can move to other PDS easily, there are few reasons to block a host due to content.

For their content labeling system, I think enabling user choice is the right direction. My doubt is whether algorithms outside the network and client can collect enough signals to do its job adequately, and how these providers monetize. So, time will till.

Hot take: Have been trying to introduce both Bluesky and Farcaster to people in tech but not crypto. The wallet login and web3 connotation have became a big obstacle to onboard more people. It will be even so when move to mainnet and pay gas to register. But CT need attention, they aren‚Äôt moving to FC neither.

I do like the ppl in FC and how easy to engage a conversation here. But I am pessimistic that it can sustain, especially after the successful take off of Bluesky. People seeking attention would prefer Bluesky over Farcaster, but people who enjoy conversation is turned off by web3 hurdles.

Major changes to FC are needed for survival. Here are things that needed: while as I understand Ethereum is essential in making the identifier not under centralized control (which is an unsolved problem in Bluesky), but normies can‚Äôt use it and don‚Äôt care. The web3 bits should be abstracted away from the UX.

An even more drastic change is changing the underlying protocol to be compatible with AT Protocol so that content are shared with Bluesky, but Warpcast become a community-focused client with heavy investment in filter algorithms. Good parts like short user handles could be kept as an extension to ATP.
The entire flow. I think it is not that it is too hard for people to understand, and people have no motivation to learn this new thing.

I agree that the exclusivity help keep the quality of the community. But the problem is that Farcaster can‚Äôt be kept at few thousands users scale forever. This scale can‚Äôt sustain a protocol, especially not with 30M investment from a16z. This size isn‚Äôt attractive to app developers too.

Software update without resetting the key is always a potential backdoor, even before this update. But I doubt if this update give them the ability to extract the key if user did not opt in.

I think a bigger problem is Ledger‚Äôs lack of communication. There is no technical documents nor detailed recovery procedures for public review. And I don‚Äôt understand why they choose real ID-based over social recovery. But I think improving recovery process is a welcomed feature if you want crypto to be mainstream.

Arguably the ability to update firmware without resetting private keys is already a backdoor, allowing them to push firmware that exfiltrate keys. Having an opt-in feature that allow the keys to be escrowed doesn‚Äôt make it worse.

How deep you want to go into and where are you at? There are few books I could recommend depends on what you want?

There are primitives like block/stream cipher, public key crypto, and hash. And then building blocks like key exchange. And there are protocols like TLS and Signal.

As engineer go with the highest level possible, e.g. using Signal protocol, rather than roll your own crypto. But for academic interest there are books.

For an introductory book I would recommend Real-World Cryptography from David Wong and Serious Cryptography from Jean-Philippe Aumasson. Cryptography Engineering from Niels Ferguson is older but covers some non-technical thinking in designing a secure system.

The Moderators‚Äô Trilemma by Alan Rozenshtein:

Running a platform with a large and diverse user base; Attempting to use a centralized, top-down content moderation policies; Avoid angering their users.

Am I the only one who don‚Äôt like the EU replaceable batteries regulations? The phone will soon be made worse for zero environmental benefits.

I am fine with slightly thicker phone if the regulation could indeed reduce electronic waste. But there is no logical reason it is the case. They could have just mandate manufacturers to service batteries for free for 6 years which incentives easier repair and better battery tech, without crippling the design.
